sn56.41:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
sn56.41:1.2: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
sn56.41:1.3: “Once upon a time, mendicants, a certain person left Rājagaha, thinking ‘I’ll speculate about the world.’ They went to the Sumāgadhā lotus pond and sat down on the bank speculating about the world.
sn56.41:1.4: Then that person saw an army of four divisions enter a lotus stalk.
sn56.41:1.5: When he saw this he thought,
sn56.41:1.6: ‘I’ve gone mad, really, I’ve lost my mind!
sn56.41:1.7: I’m seeing things that don’t exist in the world.’
sn56.41:2.1: Then that person entered the city and informed a large crowd,
sn56.41:2.2: ‘I’ve gone mad, really, I’ve lost my mind!
sn56.41:2.3: I’m seeing things that don’t exist in the world.’
sn56.41:2.4: ‘But how is it that you’re mad? How have you lost your mind?
sn56.41:2.5: And what have you seen that doesn’t exist in the world?’
sn56.41:2.6: ‘Sirs, I left Rājagaha, thinking “I’ll speculate about the world.” I went to the Sumāgadhā lotus pond and sat down on the bank speculating about the world.
sn56.41:2.7: Then I saw an army of four divisions enter a lotus stalk.
sn56.41:2.8: That’s why I’m mad, that’s why I’ve lost my mind.
sn56.41:2.9: And that’s what I’ve seen that doesn’t exist in the world.’
sn56.41:2.10: ‘Well, mister, you’re definitely mad, you’ve definitely lost your mind.
sn56.41:2.11: And you’re seeing things that don’t exist in the world.’
sn56.41:3.1: But what that person saw was in fact real, not unreal.
sn56.41:3.2: Once upon a time, a battle was fought between the gods and the demons.
sn56.41:3.3: In that battle the gods won and the demons lost.
sn56.41:3.4: The defeated and terrified demons entered the demon city through the lotus stalk only to confuse the gods.
sn56.41:4.1: So mendicants, don’t speculate about the world.
sn56.41:4.2: For example: the cosmos is eternal, or not eternal, or finite, or infinite; the soul and the body are the same thing, or they are different things; after death, a Realized One exists, or doesn’t exist, or both exists and doesn’t exist, or neither exists nor doesn’t exist.
sn56.41:4.4: Because those thoughts aren’t beneficial or relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. They don’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
sn56.41:5.1: When you think something up, you should think: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
sn56.41:5.3: Because those thoughts are beneficial and relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. They lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
sn56.41:6.1: That’s why you should practice meditation …”
